question: Bollock naked with his socks still on?
What for? Protective purposes?
Ask Jack. It's his old stamping ground.
What? And get the clap? You work for us, Jack. We have connections in those parts. I'd hate you to screw 'em up. What's that? A python. What are you going for?
Some hard nuts operate up there, Jack. They won't take kindly to someone from London poking his bugle in.

Pint of bitter. In a thin glass. Yes. Hello? Margaret? Why the hell aren't you here? What time? Is Doreen at the house? Who's with him then? When can I see you? Will you be there tomorrow? Now listen, Margaret... I won't be using the room tonight.
I'm staying with a friend.
answer: Her husband docks tomorrow, does he?

question: It's not like that, luv.
answer: It never is. Are you a traveller?

question: Definitely.
Very nice. I'll pay you for tonight as well.
answer: Don't be bloody silly. You're the first since Monday.

question: You sure?
I'll bet this one's seen some action.
answer: I'll give you the key when you come down.

question: Was he in bad shape? Doreen? All right, are you? Been staying with a friend? Sorry about your father.
Tell me, Doreen, did the police say anything?
How's school?
Oh, what you doing now?
That must be interesting.
I couldn't believe it when I heard. Carter is suddenly attentive.
I mean, I was surprised when he didn't turn up for work. He was always on time.
answer: Did you work with him, Keith?

question: Yeah. A bloody funny thing! Is that Margaret? Margaret.
answer: Changed me mind. Everyhing go off all right?

question: Fine... I want to talk to you.
Doreen.
answer: She's nothing to do with me.

question: What do you mean? You've been Frank's bird ever since her mother cleared off. You're closer to her than anyone.
answer: No. No. It's not like that. I've got a husband, you know.

question: Hold it! Hold it! Who killed Frank, Margaret?
answer: Killed? I don't know anything about it.

question: Really.
answer: I must go. I'm in a hurry.

question: I want to talk to you later.
Tomorrow morning, then?
answer: Well, all right then. Twelve o'clock on the Iron Bridge.

question: What? You mean, like, kill himself? Naw. Frank? Kill himself? You what? I mean, what for?
Come off it. Frank was... well... straight. He had no worries I know. Hell, we worked together every day for a year. It would have showed.
It just would. He was always the same.
answer: Since when did he drink whisky?

question: Don't know.
Let her go. She'll be OK. Sorry about that.
answer: Don't worry. She's bound to be upset.

question: Have another?
answer: No. I'll be off now. I should be at work.

question: Look, look. Get your suit cleaned.
Thanks for coming.
answer: Frank was a good bloke. It's the least I could have done.

question: You work here, Keith?
Keith, if anybody comes in here and asks for me, you let me know. Right?
I'm at the Las Vegas. Behind the dance hall. Do you know a man called Albert Swift?
answer: Yeah. He comes in here a bit.

question: Where would I find him?
answer: Today? At the races. He always goes. How'd you know Albert?

question: Went to school with him. He was leader of our gang. He'll know what's going on in this town. Grey suits you, Eric.
Is he?
Eric. Eric Paice.
answer: What you doing around here then?

question: Didn't you know this is my home town?
Funny, that.
answer: Thanks. So what're you doing? On your holidays?

question: No. I'm visiting relatives.
It would be. If they were still living.
A bereavement. A death in the family.
answer: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that.

question: That's all right, Eric.
answer: Well, well. Small world, isn't it?

question: Very... So, who you working for these days Eric?
What are you doing? Advertising Martini?
Yeah, Come off it, Eric. Who is it? Brumby? Kinnear?
I've always ad your welfare at heart, Eric. Besides which, I'm nosy.
answer: That's not always a healthy way to be...

question: And you should know, if I remember rightly. So you're doing all right then, Eric. You're making good.
Good prospects for advancement, is there? A pension? Do you know, I'd almost forgotten what your eyes looked like. They're still the same. Piss holes in the snow.
answer: Still got a sense of humour?

question: Yes, I retained that, Eric. Do you know a man called Albert Swift, Eric?
Don't miss the start on my account.
You see what it's like these days, Jack. You can't get the material.
answer: Yes, I can see your problem, Mr Kinnear.

question: Sit down, Jack, I could weep. I really could. Sometimes I think I'll retire. Just piss off to the Bahamas and let somebody else employ them, Glenda, get Jack a drink. What is it, Jack?
Piss off, Ray. Eric told me of your bereavement.
Do you know, I never knew he worked in one of my places!
answer: No? Funny that. Neither did I.

question: If I'd known, I'd have fixed him up with something better.
Nasty way to go.
Right. If you can afford it.
Soon. When you've lost your money. Won't take long.
You know Sid Fletcher?
You know Sid Fletcher?
Do you?
What's that? A hundred?
Your hundred, and another hundred. What's that?
answer: That, Harry? That's another hundred - twenty-five pounds notes of the realm.

question: Three hundred altogether?
I know him too.
Sid Fletcher.
Yes.
Yes. I met him last year.
Oh yes. When he came up on business.
He came to see Mr Kinnear.
What's that?
answer: That's six hundred pounds, Harry. Two hundred to follow you, and I've raised it four hundred.

question: Four hundred?
You're not seeing me?
I'll see you, then.
answer: Calling my bluff, are you, Harry?

question: We went about together.
Yes, while he was here.
answer: While he was here. You went about together?

question: He was here for four days.
Could you do me a favour?
answer: Yeah, I'll do you a favour.

question: Yeah, I'll do that. Told you it wouldn't take long, didn't I?
You should have told me who you were working for.
Oh, Cyril, eh? So it's all girls together, is it?
answer: He's thinking Sid and Gerald won't like it much when they hear you've been sticking your nose in.

question: He's right. Tell him to save the cost of the phone call.
What happened to this car?
answer: What's it got to do with you?

question: This is my brother's car.
Yeah.
answer: Well, he drove it into the river.

question: Was the steering faulty? What about the brakes?
How'd it happen, then?
answer: He was drunk. Drunk as a lord.

question: Was he?
Large Scotch.
answer: Heard of a man called Thorpe?

question: Old Thorpey? Haven't seen him in a long time.
answer: That's what he was saying about you. Said he'd heard you were up in town. Wondered if I knew where you was staying. Wanted to look you up. Old time's sake.

question: That's nice. What'd you tell him?
Good lad. See you later.
Las Vegas. You all right now?
You coming to South America?
Where you going to live, then?
Where's that?
Nice family, are they? Church-goers and all that? Good. I'm off tomorrow, so I don't suppose I'll see you again. There. Go and get your hair done.
Be good. And don't trust boys.
answer: That was left for you this evening. What is it?

question: My brother, Frank.
Funny. Can I phone London?
Jack?
I'd like a word with you, Jack.
Confidential, like.
answer: You stay in the car. I'll come and listen. What you want to tell me, Thorpey?

question: I've been asked to give you this. Train goes at four minutes past twelve. You've just got time.
answer: That's very kind of somebody. Who do I have to thank? What happens if I miss the train?

question: I've been asked to make sure you don't.
answer: Oh, really. You're getting very optimistic in your old age, aren't you, Thorpey?

question: Are you coming, Jack? It'd be best. Right lads.
answer: Thorpe! Time's up, Thorpey. Hello, Keith, Stay there, Thorpey.

question: Thorpe! Time's up, Thorpey. Hello, Keith, Stay there, Thorpey.
answer: What the bloody hell do you think you're at?

question: I'm sorry.
No. Really, I am.
answer: Don't come that bloody flannel with me. If you're a traveller, I'm bloody Twiggy. And who's he?

question: We're going inside.
answer: Inside? Why should I give house- room to your sort?

question: Up the stairs, Keith. The door on the right.
answer: You keep your trap shut, Ma. And wouldn't he love it! Where do you think you're going?

question: Why don't you go and make us all a nice cup of tea?
answer: And what you going to do?

question: Make us a nice cup of tea and I'll tell you. I might even let you watch.

No, you won't. Well now, Thorpey. It seems I've got a secret benefactor. It's nice to know that. Isn't it, Keith? There's only one trouble, I don't know who to thank. Now, I want to know who it is, Thorpey. All right. If you like, Thorpey, we'll stop mucking about. Somebody doesn't want me poking my nose into something and I happen to know what that something is. Now stand up. Who paid you to see me off?
answer: I can't Jack. How can I?

question: Yes you can.
Who sent you, Thorpey?
There you are, you see. Now you could, couldn't you? And quickly. Ah, Edna, come in. Join the tea set.
Cliff Brumby. Ever been to Westsea? Ever been into an arcade there and put a penny in the slot machine?
Jesus wept!
I'll murder the little bitch!

That's right, bloody Daddy. And this is what you call having a few friends back for coffee, is it? Running bloody riot over my bloody furniture, drinking my bloody booze... ... spewing over my fucking goldfish.
Good evening.
I'm an old friend of Cliff's. I want to see him. It's urgent.
Business.
answer: I know all about Cliff's business.

question: Yeah, well, tell him the Fletchers sent me.
answer: What the bloody hell's all this? You know what the bloody time is! It's two o'clock in the bloody morning!

question: I know.
answer: Well? The wife says the Fletchers sent you. What's so bloody important it couldn't wait till the morning? Listen, I'm not in the mood for bloody silly buggers.

question: I made a mistake.
I made a mistake.
Never mind.
See you.
answer: Listen, I don't like it when some hard nut comes pushing his way in and out my house in the middle of the night. Bloody well tell me who sent you.

question: You sod.
No. Look at this. You bastard. You don't care a stuff, do you?
What about the lad? They took him away. What'll they do to him?
They bloody hurt me.
answer: You're lucky. They kill as well.

question: And what about you? Did you kill Brumby? Thorpey nearly died laughing.
What about Keith?
What you going to do?
You're a bastard.
answer: What am I supposed to do? I don't know where they've taken him. Do you? So shut up.

question: What's that gun doing in your room? Suppose I phoned the police and told them there's a bloke staying in my hotel who's planning to shoot somebody?
How'd you know I wouldn't?
answer: 'Cos I know you wear purple underwear.

question: What's that supposed to mean?
Are you awake?
Do you want breakfast?
answer: You must be joking. I never eat breakfast, Did you sleep well?

question: Uh-huh. Did you sleep well?
answer: Yes, thank you. Are you tired?

question: No. Are you tired?
answer: No. I'm not tired, Do you eat breakfast?

question: Do us a favour?
answer: What, and get myself beaten up again?

question: No chance of that.
They're friends of mine.
answer: And that'll make me feel better?

question: Strawberry Fair. In. Turn right. Open that door. And go inside.
I'm going to sit in the car and whistle 'Rule, Britannia'.
Keith in? Which is his room? What happened to you, then?
Did they give you a rough time?
answer: No. You bastard. You knew they'd come back.

question: No, I didn't, Does Albert Swift still live over the ferry?
All right. All right. I want to square things with you first.
answer: Oh yes? How? Stuff it! My girl friend's coming from Liverpool tonight. Nice surprise, isn't it?

question: I'm sorry. Here. This'll pay for a course in karate.
answer: Frank said you were a shit and he was bloody well right. You even screwed his wife, didn't you? The poor bastard didn't even know if the kid was his.

question: How were things between you and Frank?
answer: He was all right to me.

question: Nothing more? Just another feller?
But he was just another feller, wasn't he?
Though nicer than most?
answer: Yes. I can't help the way I am.

question: Why'd you see him so regular?
I call that regular.
answer: He was gentlemanly. I like that.

question: Once a week you like a gentleman?
answer: Look, I'm me, right. You're not. We are what we are, like it or not. Why all the bloody needle?

question: What was bugging Frank?
answer: He wanted me to leave Dave and marry him. Last Friday I told him it wouldn't work. Dave would have killed us both! He followed me home and kicked up a stink in the street, I had to tell Frank I couldn't see him any more. It was getting too dodgy. That was on Sunday. He said he'd kill himself. I was frightened what you might do.

question: I don't believe you, Margaret. Frank wasn't like that. I'm the villain in the family, remember?
answer: It's the truth. It is. Honestly.

question: You bloody whore. Frank was too careful to die like that. Who killed him?
Listen, the only reason I came back to this craphole was to find out who did it. And I won't leave until I do. You understand?
You bitch! It was you who told them I was here, wasn't it?
answer: Peter's very upset about his car. He's going to shit all over you.

question: Over here, Jack. You didn't know you had a fairy godmother, did you?
A fairy godmother, all of your own. Aren't you lucky?
answer: So where are we going, Princess?

question: To the demon king's castle, of course.
answer: Of course. Where else? How'd you know where I'd be?

question: You were seen parking your car. The demon king waves his wand and I was dispatched to bring you to him. Lucky for you I waited.
answer: Very lucky, I should think. You're drunk!

question: Nasty.
answer: He must have been pretty sure I'd come.

question: Oh, he was. He told me a magic spell that would make you come.
A new venture of mine. It's going to be a restaurant. Do you like it?

Last night, after you'd gone, I did a little bit of asking around. Seeing as you weren't very forthcoming, It seems that you are concerned about the death of your brother? I got to thinking it would be nice if the bloke you were after was the same bloke I wanted off my back, You know my life. Machines. The arcades. Nice business. Looks after itself. People put money in. I take it out. Not much rough stuff. It's a business that makes me very happy. But recently, I've had a spot of bother, One of my lads gets a bit over- anxious and flogs some machines in a club that's already got some. The upshot is I've had to eat shit and stop flogging my machines to other clubs. So far as I'm concerned, that's it. Apparently not. These people I've offended get the idea that it would be good to take over my whole outfit, So I'm worried. I can't fight them  I haven't that kind of set-up. But I've got to fix them before they fix me. Trouble is, if I try and they find out, I'm dead. Five grand. It belongs to you. Along with a little name I'm going to give you.
Kinnear. Cyril Kinnear. Kinnear did it.
I don't know. All I know is that people were shitting bricks up at his place last Saturday. Your brother's name was mentioned. Next day, he was dead.
I don't know. That's all I was told.
Christ, what...
answer: Do me a favour. You don't really expect me to fix Kinnear on your say-so? Just because they tried to get me on you last night, don't think you can pull the same trick. Stroll on.

question: Jack, you're wrong.
answer: Good afternoon, Mr Brumby. Carter exits.

question: Jack...
answer: Who's setting you up in this place?

question: Who's setting you up in this place?
Is he coming here?
answer: Don't worry. He's meeting the architects at the restaurant.

question: Aren't you scared Kinnear will find out?
answer: He won't. He thinks I'm simple.

question: What does he want that bloody great country place for?
What kind of entertaining?
Does Brumby get a kick out of that crap?
answer: Especially when I play the lead.

question: Did Kinnear say anything? After I'd left the other night?
answer: That's why you waited for me.

question: Not entirely. No.
Sure I'm sure.
I want to give you an Oscar.
Tell me about the girl.
The young girl. Who pulled her?
Was it Albert?
Is it one of Kinnear's films?
Who set it up? Eric?
Then he must have pulled her.
Did my brother Frank find out?
answer: Your brother? What you talking about?

question: You're a lying bitch. Now tell me the truth.
answer: The girl's name was Doreen. That's all I know.

question: And you didn't know her last name?

Well, it's Carter. That's my name, And her father was my brother. And he was murdered last Sunday. Now get up and get dressed. Get in. Where's Albert? Where's Albert? I know where I'll find him. Hello, Albert.
answer: Hello, Jack, I don't know anything, Jack.

question: Yes, you do, Albert. Talk or I'll kill you.
Do you want to go to the toilet, Albert? Do you want to go to the toilet, Albert? You can't get away from me, Albert.
answer: I know. For Christ's sake, give us a fag. I didn't know who Doreen was. Thought she was just another bird.

question: Did Eric Pake pull her?
How?
answer: I dunno. He's got his ways. He knows Margaret.

question: When did you find out?
How?
answer: No choice. I had a visit from somebody.

question: Who?
answer: Cliff Brumby. He'd seen the film. He wanted to meet Doreen.

question: And you told Brumby? Who killed Frank? Do you want to be dead, Albert?
answer: Last Sunday afternoon, Eric and two of his boys arrive with Frank and tell me that he's rumbled. Somehow, he's seen the film and was about to shoot his mouth off. They ask me for some whisky and start forcing it down his throat. I thought they'd just duff him up a bit. Honest.

question: What did you do? Albert?
Did Eric know that Frank was my brother?
What did he say?
Is that all there is? Then that's it, Albert.
You knew what I'd do.
answer: Yes, but listen. Christ, I didn't kill him.

question: Hello, Gerald.
answer: It's Carter. Listen carefully, you hairy-faced git. I've got the film and enough evidence to put you away for a long time. All it takes is one call to the police.

question: Really? So?
answer: I'll do a simple deal with you. All I want is ...

question: I see. I think that can be arranged.
answer: ... but I don't want him there until six in the morning. OK? Right.
